definition: to protect/to defend/to guard against/to prevent

sentences.english: As a prevention against diseases people should be inoculated.
sentences.chinese: 作爲一種預防疾病的措施，人們應該打預防針。

sentences.english: He ought to have been inoculated.
A health worker immunizes an infant in Nepal.
sentences.chinese: 醫療工作者在尼泊爾爲嬰兒注射預防針。

sentences.english: Your son ought to be inoculated against smallpox.
sentences.chinese: 你兒子應當注射預防天花的預防針。

sentences.english: Li You, too, will have to be inoculated for the yellow paper when you've got the visa.
sentences.chinese: 等你有了簽證，你也得打預防針才能得到黃皮書。

sentences.english: The children are going to the hospital to be inoculated.
sentences.chinese: 孩子們將去醫院打預防針。

sentences.english: He gets a vaccination. I hope there aren't any side effects.
sentences.chinese: 他打預防針，希望沒有什麼副作用。

sentences.english: Today, I went to get the vaccination my college requires of all students.
sentences.chinese: 今天，學校要求全體學生打預防針，我就去了。

sentences.english: One of the best ways to do so is vaccination.
sentences.chinese: 全球枕戈待旦最好的方法，就是打疫苗預防針。
肺炎預防針是非常安全的。

sentences.english: If, unfortunately, bitten by dog, please go to the hospital at once and get inoculated.
sentences.chinese: 如不幸被狗咬傷，請即到醫院處理傷口並打預防針。

sentences.english: Giving people a vaccination greatly reduces the occurrence of flu in the population.
sentences.chinese: 打預防針大幅度降低了患流感的人數。

sentences.english: Everyone who is going abroad will need to be immunised against typhoid.
sentences.chinese: 準備出國者均需注射傷寒預防針。

sentences.english: I had a flu shot last week.
sentences.chinese: 我上週便打了流感預防針。

sentences.english: Have you received three or more vaccinations?
sentences.chinese: 你曾打過三種以上不同的預防針嗎？

sentences.english: Do you know or think you need a tetanus shot?
sentences.chinese: 你是否知道或者認爲你需要打預防針？

definition: to ignore/to brush off/to dismiss/to pay no attention to
to injure by scratching or clawing
counting one's chickens before they are hatched
strike first and gain the upper hand (idiom, martial arts term); Making the first move is an advantage.
to feel guilty as a thief (idiom); to have sth on one's conscience
(idiom) to lose one's head/to panic/to go to pieces
spendthrift and foolish/sb with more money than sense
to reveal the cloven foot (idiom); to unmask one's true nature/to give the game away
